title: Invited team member can disclosure slack channels

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:
Hello, this report is similar to #505493 (also still waiting for response), but accent is totally on another thing. I think it is important and should be fixed, and so i create new report.

Invited team member without any permission can disclosure private channel names of slack integration.

If it is also by design, i very hope that it should be fixed.

For example, user1 and user2 can be in one slack team and one hackerone team, but user1 can't view names of some private slack channels in which he not invited. But he can disclosure it names by making graphql query to hackerone

Description:
Using graphql query

query{

  teams(where:{handle:{_eq:"hackeronetest_4hr1y"}}){
    edges{
      node{
        slack_pipelines{
          nodes{
            id
            descriptive_label
            team{
              handle
              slack_integration{
                channels{
                  name
                }
              }
            }
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

invited team member(hackerone) without permission can access private slack channel names in which he not invited

Steps To Reproduce

  1. as team admin create slack integration
  2. create private channel
  3. invite new team member to hackerone team, not required that user is invited to slack team
  4. remove any permissions for this user
  5. login as invited user
  6. send graphql query as described early:

Optional: Your Environment (Browser version, Device, etc)

Optional: Supporting Material/References (Screenshots)

what channels can see invited user:
what channels can see slack admin:
what channels returns to invited user though graphql:

invited user must not view this channel name: h1test

Optional: Did you use recon data made available by HackerOne to find this vulnerability?

no

Impact

Disclosure private channels of slack integration

activities.message:
in more simple words:

user foo@bar.com is admin of slack. He create private slack channel `h1test`
user baz@bar.com don't have access to channel `h1test`, even can't view it name.

user foo@bar.com invite user baz@bar.com to hackerone team
user baz@bar.com can't manage slack integration
user baz@bar.com send graphql query and get name of `h1test`

user baz@bar.com send graphql query and get name of h1test

activities.message: For example, what if head of company create private channel with name `baz_dismissal`, and  baz@bar.com can get information that he can be dismissal, and make backdoor to the system
activities.markdown_message: For example, what if head of company create private channel with name baz_dismissal, and baz@bar.com can get information that he can be dismissal, and make backdoor to the system

activities.message: Or maybe private channel names can disclosure other secret projects, that nobody should know

activities.message:
Thank you for reporting this potential issue, 

Your report is currently being examined by the HackerOne triage team. You will receive further details, or questions, as soon as technically possible. Thanks for your patience.

Cheers,
@still

activities.message: Hmm this doesn't really feel like a big deal, those which you add into your BBP will have access to vulnerabilities, which seem more sensitive than slack handles-so you should already have a high amount of trust for those members. That being said, we like to keep least amount of access when possible and I don't know (currently) of a reason we should disclose these to non program managers. I'll triage and take a look.
activities.markdown_message: Hmm this doesn't really feel like a big deal, those which you add into your BBP will have access to vulnerabilities, which seem more sensitive than slack handles-so you should already have a high amount of trust for those members. That being said, we like to keep least amount of access when possible and I don't know (currently) of a reason we should disclose these to non program managers. I'll triage and take a look.

activities.message: Hi, can't totally agree with you. Imagine not big company, with head of company, team lead and developer. Team lead manage slack and BBP, he invite developer to bug bounty team. But i really believe, that between team lead and head of company, head of company and marketing or budget, can exists secrets channels, to which developer can't access and disclosure it names can be more seriously than info about bugs in code, to which developer already have access
activities.markdown_message: Hi, can't totally agree with you. Imagine not big company, with head of company, team lead and developer. Team lead manage slack and BBP, he invite developer to bug bounty team. But i really believe, that between team lead and head of company, head of company and marketing or budget, can exists secrets channels, to which developer can't access and disclosure it names can be more seriously than info about bugs in code, to which developer already have access

activities.message: And next case. One company have two projects(prjX and prjY) with different developer teams and BBP, but in one slack team. Imagine that bbp for prjX triaged bug and create secret channel with name "fix_prjx_name_xss' and invite only developers from prjX. But developers from prjY can disclosure name of this channel and get partial info about bug, to which they don't have access.
activities.markdown_message: And next case. One company have two projects(prjX and prjY) with different developer teams and BBP, but in one slack team. Imagine that bbp for prjX triaged bug and create secret channel with name "fix_prjx_name_xss' and invite only developers from prjX. But developers from prjY can disclosure name of this channel and get partial info about bug, to which they don't have access.

activities.message: I also find doc: https://docs.hackerone.com/programs/slack-integration.html and it says only about public channels: {F442427}
activities.markdown_message: I also find doc: https://docs.hackerone.com/programs/slack-integration.html and it says only about public channels:

activities.message:
Hi @eremeev - 

Thanks for following up with us! I agree with @ben here that, given that the person is entrusted with vulnerability information, the knowledge of private Slack handles is arguably nearly as sensitive. That being said, you have made a couple of good points here - 1) it might be a bigger deal for bigger teams, and 2) it's generally a good practice to follow least principle of least privilege and not expose unnecessary information.

I have triaged this to relevant engineering team, and will keep you updated.

activities.message: Thanks for the report! Happy hunting!
Hey @eremeev, we've pushed out a fix, can you check that it's resolved? Thanks!
